questionText: No bananas here ___ available.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Bananas" is plural, so the verb must be "are".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Is" is singular. "Was" and "were" are past tense, but this sentence is present.

questionText: Each of the students ___ responsible for their own project.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Each" is always treated as singular, so the verb must be "is".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Are" and "were" are plural. "Be" is not a valid verb form here.

questionText: Some ___ the students were late this morning.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! Use "some of the" when referring to a specific group.
feedback_wrong: ❌ Only "of" fits grammatically here. "From," "for," and "to" are incorrect prepositions in this context.

questionText: There were two options. One was fruit, and ___ was meat.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! When only two items are involved, "the other" refers to the second and final one.
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Another" implies more than two. "Others" is plural. "One more" is informal and ungrammatical here.

questionText: Neither a teacher nor the students ___ in the classroom.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! When the subject closest to the verb is plural ("students"), use a plural verb.
feedback_wrong: ❌ In "Neither A nor B" constructions, the verb agrees with the noun closest to it. Here, that's "students" → plural.

questionText: All of the information ___ available on the website.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Information" is an uncountable noun, so use a singular verb: "is".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Information" is uncountable. Even with "all of", the verb must stay singular. "Are" and "were" are plural; "have" is incorrect here.

questionText: Each student must submit ___ own application form.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Each student" is singular, so we use the singular pronoun "his or her".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Each student" is grammatically singular. Use "his or her" for gender-neutral singular reference. "Their" is informal, and "their own" is redundant and ungrammatical here.

questionText: All the students ___ completed the assignment.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "All the students" is plural, so use the plural verb "have".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Has" is singular, and "was" is past singular. "Did" is possible but doesn’t match the form of the verb "completed" here.

questionText: No manuscripts ___ available in the archive today.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Manuscripts" is a plural noun, so we use the plural verb "are".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Manuscripts" is plural. Use "are" to agree in number. "Is", "was", and "has" are singular verbs.

questionText: Some of the graduate students ___ planning to attend the conference.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Some of the graduate students" is plural and requires a plural verb — "are".
feedback_wrong: ❌ Use "are" to match the plural subject "students". The other verbs are singular and do not agree in number.

questionText: Either of the proposals ___ acceptable to the committee.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Either of" takes a singular verb even though it's followed by a plural noun.
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Either of the proposals" is grammatically singular, so use "is". "Are" and "were" are plural.

questionText: Both of the arguments ___ flawed in different ways.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Both of" refers to two items together, so use the plural verb "were".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Both of" is always plural. Use "were", not singular verbs like "was" or "is".

questionText: None of the students ___ completed the assignment on time.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "None of the students" is followed by a plural countable noun, so we use the plural verb "have".
feedback_wrong: ❌ The noun "students" is plural, so the verb must also be plural. Use "have", not singular verbs like "has" or "is".

questionText: Most of the data ___ been processed correctly.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Data" is usually treated as uncountable in modern English, so "has" is correct.
feedback_wrong: ❌ In modern usage, "data" is often treated as an uncountable noun, so use "has" — not "have" or "are".

questionText: Several ___ in the program were offered internships abroad.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Several" must be followed by a plural noun — "students".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Several" is a quantifier that requires a plural noun (not singular or possessive). The correct form is "students".

questionText: The number of international students ___ increased significantly this year.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “The number of” is treated as a singular subject, so use “has”.
feedback_wrong: ❌ “The number of” refers to a total count and takes a singular verb (has). “A number of” would use a plural verb.

questionText: A number of researchers ___ expressed interest in the conference.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “A number of” is followed by a plural noun, and takes a plural verb (“have”).
feedback_wrong: ❌ “A number of” means “several” and takes a plural verb. Use “have” here.

questionText: She has very ___ experience in academic writing, so she asked for help.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “Experience” is uncountable, so use “little” (not “few”).
feedback_wrong: ❌ Use “little” with uncountable nouns like “experience.” “Few” is used with countable nouns like “problems” or “students.”

questionText: Few applicants ___ the required qualifications.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “Applicants” is countable and plural, so use “few” + have.
feedback_wrong: ❌ “Few” is used with plural countable nouns, and the verb must agree: “Few applicants have...”

questionText: Quite a few students ___ submitted their papers early.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “Quite a few” behaves like “many,” so it takes a plural noun and plural verb.
feedback_wrong: ❌ “Quite a few” means “many” and is followed by a plural noun + plural verb: “students have”.

questionText: I don't have ___ money, so I can't afford that course.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! In negative sentences, “much” is used with uncountable nouns like “money.”
feedback_wrong: ❌ Use “much” in negative sentences with uncountable nouns like “money.” “Many” is for countable nouns.

questionText: Neither the students nor the teacher are present in the classroom.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! The verb should agree with the subject closest to it. Since "teacher" is singular, use "is".
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. The verb must agree with the closest subject ("teacher"), so it should be "is present".

questionText: Each of the students are responsible for their own work.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Each" is singular and takes a singular verb, so it should be "is responsible".
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. "Each" is singular and must be followed by a singular verb, not "are".

questionText: None of the books is missing from the shelf.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “None of” with plural nouns typically takes a plural verb: “are missing”.
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. With plural nouns, “none of” usually takes a plural verb, so “is missing” is wrong here.

questionText: Some of students have completed the project on time.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! When using “some” with a plural noun without “of,” no article or determiner should follow. It should be “Some students...”
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. “Some of students” is incorrect because “some of” must be followed by a definite noun phrase like “some of the students.”

questionText: ___ both parents are quite well-educated.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! "Both" comes before the possessive pronoun "their".
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect word order. "Their both parents" is ungrammatical.

questionText: The bus arrives ___ two hours.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! Use "every" with plural time expressions like "two hours".
feedback_wrong: ❌ "Every" is the correct quantifier for repeated time intervals, not "each," "all," or "any".

questionText: Either of the brothers ___ a tall nose.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “Either” is singular, so use the singular verb “has”.
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. “Either” requires a singular verb, so “have” and “are” are wrong.

questionText: Each of the proposals ___ being considered separately.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! 'Each' is singular, so we use 'is' here.
feedback_wrong: ❌ 'Each' is singular, not plural, so 'are' and 'have' are incorrect.

questionText: Neither the manager or the employees are available for the meeting.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! The correct correlative conjunction is “Neither…nor,” not “Neither…or.”
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. “Neither…or” is ungrammatical; use “Neither…nor” for correct sentences.

questionText: Some students like the class, and ___ do not.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! 'Others' refers to some additional members, not necessarily all remaining.
feedback_wrong: ❌ 'The others' implies the full remaining group, but the sentence makes a general comparison.

questionText: Some of the students passed the exam, while ___ did not.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! 'The others' refers to the remaining known group who didn't pass.
feedback_wrong: ❌ 'Others' implies some but not necessarily all — 'the others' is more specific and accurate here.

questionText: There were two books on the table. I took one, and ___ is still there.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “The other” refers to the second item in a set of two.
feedback_wrong: ❌ “Another” is used for an additional item, not the second of two.

questionText: I don’t like this pen. Can I borrow ___ one?
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “Another” means an additional one, not previously mentioned.
feedback_wrong: ❌ “The other” refers to a specific other item already known.

questionText: One of the students ___ responsible for organizing the event.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “One” is singular, so it requires the singular verb “is”.
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. The subject “One” is singular, so use “is” rather than “are”.

questionText: Some of the students ___ completed the assignment early.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “Some of the students” refers to multiple people, so use the plural verb “have.”
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. The subject is plural, so use “have” rather than “has.”

questionText: Which book do you want to borrow? This one looks not so interesting. So, I will borrow ___ one.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “The other one” refers to the second specific item among two known options.
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. “The other one” is used when referring to a specific, previously mentioned item, not “another” or “others.”

questionText: This apple is a bit rotten. I will pick ___ one.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! “Another one” means an additional, different item.
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. “Another” is used when selecting an additional item, not “the other” or “others.” “Their” is a possessive pronoun, so it doesn’t fit here.

questionText: Some people are smart, and ___ are honest.
feedback_correct: ✅ Correct! Both “some” refer to different subsets without implying the rest of the group.
feedback_wrong: ❌ Incorrect. Using “others” or “the others” implies contrasting with the rest of the group explicitly.
